channel.title: World
channel.description: NPR world news, international art and culture, world business and financial markets, world economy, and global trends in health, science and technology. Subscribe to the World Story of the Day podcast and RSS feed.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: Yazidi Community In America Watches Events In Iraq With Horror
item.description: Lincoln, Neb., is home to a sizable group of Iraqi Yazidis, members of the minority group being persecuted in Iraq. One of them, Sulaiman Murad, describes the agony of watching the crisis from afar.
item.content:encoded:
Lincoln, Neb., is home to a sizable group of Iraqi Yazidis, members of the minority group being persecuted in Iraq. One of them, Sulaiman Murad, describes the agony of watching the crisis from afar.

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: NPR Staff

item.title: Fighting Escalates In Eastern Ukraine As Key Cities Contested
item.description: Government forces and pro-Russian separatists are fighting for control. In Berlin, the Foreign Ministers of Germany, France, Russia and Ukraine met to try to figure out a way to stop the fighting.
item.content:encoded:
Government forces and pro-Russian separatists are fighting for control. In Berlin, the Foreign Ministers of Germany, France, Russia and Ukraine met to try to figure out a way to stop the fighting.

» E-Mail This

item.title: Israel, Palestinians Still Far Apart As Truce Nears End
item.description: Hamas wants an easing of the blockade of the territory, but Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has reiterated a demand for security guarantees.
item.content:encoded:
Hamas wants an easing of the blockade of the territory, but Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has reiterated a demand for security guarantees.

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: Scott Neuman

item.title: Young Indians And Pakistanis Rewrite Their Shared History
item.description: When students from the two countries met in the U.S., they were surprised at how different their history lessons had been at home. So they put together a narrative that offers both versions.
item.content:encoded:
When students from the two countries met in the U.S., they were surprised at how different their history lessons had been at home. So they put together a narrative that offers both versions.

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: Tanvi Misra

item.title: Kurds: U.S. Air Power Backing Operation To Retake Mosul Dam
item.description: Peshmerga fighters claim to have retaken the area around the dam, but an eyewitness tells NPR that he's seen no clear progress as yet by Kurdish forces.
item.content:encoded:
Peshmerga fighters claim to have retaken the area around the dam, but an eyewitness tells NPR that he's seen no clear progress as yet by Kurdish forces.

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: Scott Neuman

item.title: Kenya Shuts Borders To Ebola-Hit West African Countries
item.description: The ban on travelers from Sierra Leone, Liberia and Guinea goes into effect from midnight Tuesday.
item.content:encoded:
The ban on travelers from Sierra Leone, Liberia and Guinea goes into effect from midnight Tuesday.

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: Scott Neuman

item.title: Ukraine Claims Gains On The Ground, As Rebels Down Warplane
item.description: The MiG-29 was shot down over Luhansk, where Kiev's forces are said to have captured a police station as they tighten a circle around pro-Russia separatists.
item.content:encoded:
The MiG-29 was shot down over Luhansk, where Kiev's forces are said to have captured a police station as they tighten a circle around pro-Russia separatists.

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: Scott Neuman

item.title: Power: Leaders In South Sudan Disengaged Despite Crisis
item.description: NPR's Linda Wertheimer talks to U.S. Ambassador to the United Nations Samantha Power about her recent trip to South Sudan.
item.content:encoded:
NPR's Linda Wertheimer talks to U.S. Ambassador to the United Nations Samantha Power about her recent trip to South Sudan.

» E-Mail This

item.title: Why This Ebola Outbreak Is Different Than Earlier Versions
item.description: In 1976, Dr. David Heymann of the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine helped curb the first Ebola outbreak in what was then Zaire. He speaks with NPR's Linda Wertheimer.
item.content:encoded:
In 1976, Dr. David Heymann of the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine helped curb the first Ebola outbreak in what was then Zaire. He speaks with NPR's Linda Wertheimer.

» E-Mail This

item.title: 'Times' Reporter In Iraq Recovering After Helicopter Crash
item.description: New York Times journalist Alissa Rubin was injured in a helicopter crash in northern Iraq last week. NPR's Linda Wertheimer has an update on her recovery.
item.content:encoded:
New York Times journalist Alissa Rubin was injured in a helicopter crash in northern Iraq last week. NPR's Linda Wertheimer has an update on her recovery.

» E-Mail This

item.title: Islamic Militants Kill Dozens Of Yazidis In Northern Iraq
item.description: American fighter jets and drones carried out airstrikes against Islamist targets near the Mosul Dam in northern Iraq on Saturday. A breach of the dam could threaten entire cities.
item.content:encoded:
American fighter jets and drones carried out airstrikes against Islamist targets near the Mosul Dam in northern Iraq on Saturday. A breach of the dam could threaten entire cities.

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: Peter Kenyon

item.title: Another Front In Mideast Conflict: Fishing Rights In The Mediterranean
item.description: Israel forbids Gazan boats from going more than a few miles from shore, where the fish are few and small. Israel says the blockade is for security; Palestinians say it's illegal.
item.content:encoded:
Israel forbids Gazan boats from going more than a few miles from shore, where the fish are few and small. Israel says the blockade is for security; Palestinians say it's illegal.

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: Alice Fordham

item.title: Fighting (Tasty) Invasive Fish With Forks And Knives
item.description: Invasive fish like snakeheads and Asian carp are threatening to wipe out aquatic ecosystems across the U.S. So chefs and environmental agencies are encouraging their communities to eat them up.
item.content:encoded:
Invasive fish like snakeheads and Asian carp are threatening to wipe out aquatic ecosystems across the U.S. So chefs and environmental agencies are encouraging their communities to eat them up.

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: Bonny Wolf

item.title: Fake Cures For AIDS Have A Long And Dreadful History
item.description: The latest claim was made in Egypt: Electromagnetism can detect the virus and "the Complete Cure Device" can wipe it out. It's not the first false promise — and probably not the last.
item.content:encoded:
The latest claim was made in Egypt: Electromagnetism can detect the virus and "the Complete Cure Device" can wipe it out. It's not the first false promise — and probably not the last.

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: Susan Brink

item.title: A Year From 'Egypt's Tiananmen,' Report Surfaces On Cairo Massacre
item.description: Kenneth Roth, the executive director of Human Rights Watch, was denied entry into Egypt last week. He had been traveling to the country to present results of a report on the 2013 massacre that left at least 817 people dead in Cairo. He spoke with NPR's Arun Rath.
item.content:encoded:
Kenneth Roth, the executive director of Human Rights Watch, was denied entry into Egypt last week. He had been traveling to the country to present results of a report on the 2013 massacre that left at least 817 people dead in Cairo. He spoke with NPR's Arun Rath.

» E-Mail This
